meanings.def: to change something completely so that it is the opposite of what it was before
examples: Falling birth rates may reverse the trend towards early retirement.
to reverse a procedure/process
The government has failed to reverse the economic decline.
It is sometimes possible to arrest or reverse the disease.

meanings.def: to change a previous decision, law, etc. to the opposite one
examples: The Court of Appeal reversed the decision.
The policy is likely to be reversed if there is a change of government.
to reverse a judgement

meanings.def: to turn something the opposite way around or change the order of something around
examples: Writing is reversed in a mirror.
You should reverse the order of these pages.
To solve the puzzle, simply reverse the order of the numbers.

meanings.def: to exchange the positions or functions of two things
examples: It felt as if we had reversed our roles of parent and child.
She used to work for me, but our situations are now reversed.

meanings.def: to admit you were wrong or to stop having a particular position in an argument
examples: He has reversed himself on a dozen issues.

meanings.def: when a vehicle or its driver reverses or the driver reverses a vehicle, the vehicle goes backwards
examples: He reversed around the corner.
She reversed into a parking space.
Caution! This truck is reversing.
reverse something Now reverse the car.
He reversed slowly out of the garage.
She carefully reversed the lorry up the narrow driveway.
The car reversed into a hedge.

meanings.def: to make a phone call that will be paid for by the person you are calling, not by you
examples: I want to reverse the charges, please.

meanings.def: the opposite of what has just been mentioned
examples: This problem is the reverse of the previous one.
Although I expected to enjoy living in the country, in fact the reverse is true.
In the south, the reverse applies.
It wasn't easy to persuade her to come—quite the reverse.
If you tell children to do something, they will often do the exact reverse.

meanings.def: the back of a coin, piece of material, piece of paper, etc.
examples: The coin has a coat of arms stamped on the reverse.
The coin has a date on one side and the emperor's head on the reverse.

meanings.def: the machine in a vehicle used to make it move backwards
examples: Put the car in/into reverse.

meanings.def: a loss or defeat; a change from success to failure
examples: Property values have suffered another reverse.
a damaging political reverse
Their forces have suffered serious reverses in recent months.

meanings.def: to start to happen or to make something happen in the opposite way
examples: In 2008 economic growth went into reverse.
Various problems have put the company’s expansion plans into reverse.

meanings.def: in the opposite order or way
examples: The secret number is my phone number in reverse.
We did a similar trip to you, but in reverse.

idioms.def: to start to happen or to make something happen in the opposite way
examples: In 2008 economic growth went into reverse.
Various problems have put the company’s expansion plans into reverse.

idioms.def: in the opposite order or way
examples: The secret number is my phone number in reverse.
We did a similar trip to you, but in reverse.

meanings.def: opposite to what has been mentioned
examples: to travel in the reverse direction
The winners were announced in reverse order (= the person in the lowest place was announced first).
The experiment had the reverse effect to what was intended.
One year later she made the same journey in the reverse direction.
Iron the garment on the reverse side.
On the reverse side of the medal is a coat of arms.
